title: I’m not friends with my exes and here’s why you shouldn’t be with yours
text:
We all know how it goes. 
‘We need to talk,’ one of you says, and the deal is clear. ‘This isn’t working anymore.’
You should never ask your friends for dating advice, and here’s why You have a long conversation divulging the reasons why. There might be tears; it could get ugly.
Then, finally, once the dust is settled, one of you will say that poison phrase: ‘We can still be friends though?’
The part of you that wants to come across as a polite, reasonable and mature human being will probably think ‘yeah why not’.
They were an important part of your life, so why would you want to cut them out altogether?

You’ve seen it work for other people , why shouldn’t it work for you?
I’m sorry, but no. And you don’t have to.
You can just cut them out then and there if you want.
It doesn’t make you seem psycho or crazy to want that – in fact, some research suggests it’s the people who remain friends with their exes that have psychopathic traits.
Just saying.

In many cases, that might be the honest to god best thing you can do for yourself.
I know this because I’ve tried. I tried so hard to be friends with my exes when I was younger, to try to appear like a reasonable person, and it was awful. 
Those who read my piece about why you shouldn’t settle will be familiar with my university boyfriend. 
The one I thought was ‘The One’, but who wasn’t in the end. 
Sometimes just too much has happened (Picture: Liberty Antonia Sadler for Metro.co.uk) I chose to throw myself into my job and life in London, and that’s been great. 
It was the best decision I could have made. 
But you know what I ended up regretting the most? The question I asked myself repeatedly? 
Why didn’t I cut him out the moment we said it was over? Why did I agree to be just friends? Why, oh why.
I wonder if I could have saved myself from trying to pick myself and my broken confidence up from the floor a year after our final goodbye if I’d just blocked him on Facebook and deleted his number when we first broke up. 
Instead, I tried to be ‘mature’ about it. 
You live and learn, I suppose.
You get more bed space too I guess (Picture: Ella Byworth for Metro.co.uk) Sometimes, there are circumstances where being friends is what you need to do. 
I have dated people in the same friendship group, or who now work in the same building as me (after we were over. Awks). 
So with them, we’ve had to somewhat navigate a friendship, because it was the right thing to do, even if there were hurt feelings involved. 
While it’s all fine and I can say we all benefit from being friends now, I can’t deny that it’s been uncomfortable at times and there has been a few bumps along the way. 
Science says love’s effect on the brain is as powerful as heroin , and it’s fair to say I’ve been a victim of its seductive pull.
Like many addictive drugs, it has wonderful highs, but can also have terrible, soul-crushing lows.
So, now I know. 
If my next relationship should end, and there’s no other reason for us to communicate, that’ll be it. Complete cold turkey. 
I’ll be civil and polite if I happen to bump into you, and of course look back kindly at the good times. But a close friendship straight away? Forget it.
Unless there’s a reason why we should be friends then it’s not worth the turmoil of trying to adjust to a just-friends dynamic. 
At least, initially until I’ve got you out of my system.

I’m sorry if that sounds mean. 
You can all say it’s just me, that most of my relationships or attempts at dating have eventually ended in tears or flames (or both), so obviously any friendship afterwards wasn’t going to work. 
But if you cared about a person enough to love them, enough to open up and share the most intimate parts of yourself, then of course it’s going to be difficult if not impossible to adjust to something more platonic. 
The spark might never disappear – as it never really did with my ex during our ‘friends’ period – and it might make it difficult for you to move on if they’re still a constant presence in your life.

All I am saying is that, you don’t have to be friends with them just because it seems like the polite thing to do.
Allow yourself time to recover and get your ex, the intoxicating drug that they are, out of your system – at least at first. Then, maybe, see how it is.
Or not. You can do that too.
Many of my exes are basically dead to me now though, a figment of my past.
And I wouldn’t have it any other way.
